questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with weakness and numbness in his right arm following a motor vehicle accident. Physical examination reveals decreased sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm and weakness of elbow flexion. Which part of the brachial plexus does not give branches?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Division

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The divisions of the brachial plexus do not give rise to any branches, unlike the roots, trunks, and cords, which all contribute branches to various nerves of the upper limb.

questions.text: Pronator quadratus receives innervation from a nerve which also supplies? A. Flexor digitorum superficialis B. Flexor pollicis longus C. Flexor carpi ulnaris D. Flexor digitorum profundus in the middle finger E. Palmaris longus
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) B, D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pronator quadratus is innervated by the anterior interosseous nerve, which also supplies the flexor pollicis longus and the lateral part of the flexor digitorum profundus (middle and index fingers).

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset chest pain and dyspnea. He has a history of hypertension and is a current smoker. On physical examination, he appears anxious and diaphoretic. Vital signs are significant for tachycardia and tachypnea. Auscultation reveals diminished breath sounds on the left side. A chest X-ray shows a widened mediastinum. Further evaluation reveals a left-sided superior intercostal vein anomaly. Which vessel does the left superior intercostal vein normally drain into?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Brachiocephalic vein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The left superior intercostal vein typically drains into the left brachiocephalic vein , forming a direct connection between the upper left intercostal spaces and the central venous system.
  • ➤ left superior intercostal vein
  • ➤ left brachiocephalic vein

questions.text: A patient with syphilis is unable to walk with closed eyes and presents with a stomping gait. Name the tract involved in the given condition:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dorsal column tract

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Damage to the dorsal column tract , particularly seen in conditions like tabes dorsalis (a complication of syphilis), results in the loss of proprioception, causing difficulty walking with closed eyes and a characteristic stomping gait.
  • ➤ dorsal column tract
  • ➤ tabes dorsalis

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of altered taste sensation on the left side of her tongue. She reports recent dental surgery on that side. On examination, taste sensation is intact on the tongue bilaterally. Which cranial nerve is not associated with the taste pathway?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) XII

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII) is not involved in the taste pathway; its function is purely motor, controlling tongue movement.
  • ➤ hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII)

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the orthopedic clinic with persistent wrist pain following a fall on an outstretched hand. On examination, there is tenderness over the anatomical snuffbox and limited range of motion of the wrist joint. Radiographs reveal a fracture of the scaphoid bone. Which bone is not typically involved in the formation of the wrist joint?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ulna

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ulna is not typically involved in the formation of the wrist joint due to the presence of the articular disc, which separates it from the carpal bones.
  • ➤ ulna

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the primary care clinic with lower back pain radiating down his left leg. He reports a history of heavy lifting at work. On physical examination, there is tenderness over the lumbar vertebrae with limited lumbar spine flexion due to pain. Which anatomical curvature is normally observed in the lumbar spine?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lordosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The normal curvature of the lumbar spine is lordosis , which helps with weight distribution and maintaining proper posture.
  • ➤ lumbar spine
  • ➤ lordosis

questions.text: All the given muscles help in inversion of the foot except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Peroneus longus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The peroneus longus is involved in eversion of the foot, while muscles like the tibialis anterior and tibialis posterior contribute to inversion .
  • ➤ peroneus longus
  • ➤ eversion
  • ➤ tibialis anterior
  • ➤ tibialis posterior
  • ➤ inversion

questions.text: Arrange the given stages of spermatogenesis in the correct sequence: A. Spermatid B. Spermatozoa C. Spermatogonium D. Spermatocyte
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) C → D → A → B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of spermatogenesis is Spermatogonium → Spermatocyte → Spermatid → Spermatozoa.
  • ➤ Spermatogonium → Spermatocyte → Spermatid → Spermatozoa.

questions.text: After parotidectomy, a patient complains of loss of sensation while shaving. Which nerve is most likely affected?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Great auricular nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The great auricular nerve is commonly injured during parotid surgery, leading to loss of sensation in the shaving area (angle of the mandible and ear).
  • ➤ great auricular nerve
  • ➤ shaving area

questions.text: Which structure passes through the marked opening?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Thoracic duct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The thoracic duct passes through the aortic hiatus of the diaphragm at the T12 level, along with the aorta and azygous vein.
  • ➤ thoracic duct
  • ➤ aortic hiatus

questions.text: A patient underwent a left submandibular gland excision during which the hypoglossal nerve was injured. Which of the following deficits would be seen in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Deviated tongue to the contralateral side

options.label: B
options.text: Deviated tongue to the same side

options.label: D
options.text: Loss of taste in posterior 1/3rd of the tongue

questions.correct_answer: B. Deviated tongue to the same side
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Deviated tongue to the same side

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Injury to the hypoglossal nerve results in tongue deviation toward the same side as the injury due to paralysis of the tongue muscles on the affected side.
  • ➤ hypoglossal nerve
  • ➤ toward the same side

questions.text: A patient developed the following deformity after overhead weightlifting & pushing exercises. Which of the following muscles is involved?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Serratus anterior

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Weakness or injury to the serratus anterior muscle , typically due to damage to the long thoracic nerve , leads to a winged scapula .
  • ➤ serratus anterior muscle
  • ➤ long thoracic nerve
  • ➤ winged scapula

questions.text: A 2-week-old infant is brought to the pediatrician due to a murmur noted by the parents. On auscultation, a continuous machinery-like murmur is heard over the left upper sternal border. Echocardiography reveals a patent ductus arteriosus. Which pharyngeal arch artery does the ductus arteriosus develop from?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 6

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ductus arteriosus develops from the 6th pharyngeal arch artery , and its failure to close after birth results in a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), characterized by a continuous machinery-like murmur.
  • ➤ ductus arteriosus
  • ➤ 6th pharyngeal arch artery

questions.text: The tissue in the image is found in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Epiphyseal plates

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The tissue in the image is hyaline cartilage , which is typically found in epiphyseal plates , where it plays a crucial role in bone growth.
  • ➤ hyaline cartilage
  • ➤ epiphyseal plates

questions.text: In humans, many diseases are associated with failure of migration of neural crest cells. Neural crest cell migration is due to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hyaluronic acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neural crest cells migrate during embryogenesis with the aid of hyaluronic acid, which provides an essential framework in the extracellular matrix. Defects in this migration can lead to a variety of congenital disorders affecting craniofacial, cardiac, and other tissues.

questions.text: Which muscle is attached to the given pointed structure of the femur bone?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Iliopsoas

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The iliopsoas muscle attaches to the lesser trochanter of the femur, and its primary function is hip flexion.
  • ➤ iliopsoas muscle
  • ➤ lesser trochanter

questions.text: The type of epithelium as shown in the image below is present in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Urinary bladder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transitional epithelium is present in the urinary bladder , where it allows for expansion and contraction depending on the volume of urine.
  • ➤ Transitional epithelium
  • ➤ urinary bladder

questions.text: A student, after a heavy lunch from the hostel, got ready for his afternoon class. He sat on the first bench and began to take notes. After a while, he yawned widely. To his surprise, he could not close his mouth. The jaw was stuck. Which of the following statement is not true in the above scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: This is a case of anterior dislocation of temporomandibular joint

options.label: B
options.text: Temporomandibular joint is a bicondylar type of synovial joint

options.label: C
options.text: Contraction of medial pterygoid depresses the mandible

options.label: D
options.text: Sphenomandibular ligament is situated medial to temporomandibular joint

questions.correct_answer: C. Contraction of medial pterygoid depresses the mandible
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Contraction of medial pterygoid depresses the mandible

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The medial pterygoid muscle elevates the mandible, while depression is achieved by the lateral pterygoid muscle .
  • ➤ medial pterygoid
  • ➤ elevates
  • ➤ lateral pterygoid muscle

questions.text: The pointed structure supplies all the following parts of the conducting system in the heart:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) SA node

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The right coronary artery supplies the SA node and parts of the AV node , but it does not supply the AV bundle or the left bundle branch .
  • ➤ right coronary artery
  • ➤ SA node
  • ➤ AV node
  • ➤ AV bundle
  • ➤ left bundle branch

questions.text: Injury to the artery that lies beneath the arrow will lead to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Extradural hemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Injury to the middle meningeal artery located beneath the pterion can cause an extradural hemorrhage , a life-threatening condition that requires immediate medical attention.
  • ➤ middle meningeal artery
  • ➤ pterion
  • ➤ extradural hemorrhage

questions.text: Which artery can be palpated by gently pressing your fingers between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal (Achilles) tendon?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Posterior tibial artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The posterior tibial artery is palpated between the medial malleolus and the Achilles tendon and is an important pulse point for assessing blood flow to the foot.
  • ➤ posterior tibial artery
  • ➤ medial malleolus
  • ➤ Achilles tendon

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with complaints of recurrent episodes of food getting stuck in his throat, particularly after swallowing large pieces of meat. He describes a sensation of food bolus obstruction in the lower neck area. Barium swallow reveals an outpouching in the posterior wall of the hypopharynx. This clinical condition is located between which two muscles?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cricopharyngeus and Thyropharyngeus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Zenker's diverticulum forms between the Cricopharyngeus and Thyropharyngeus muscles, leading to a pouch in the posterior hypopharynx.
  • ➤ Zenker's diverticulum
  • ➤ Cricopharyngeus
  • ➤ Thyropharyngeus

questions.text: Which among the following aids in supination and pronation of the forearm?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pivot joint

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pivot joints , such as the proximal and distal radioulnar joints, are responsible for the rotational movements of supination and pronation in the forearm.
  • ➤ Pivot joints
  • ➤ supination and pronation

questions.text: Which structure is advised to occlude in ligation of the splenic artery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ligation of the splenic artery should occur at the hilum of the spleen to effectively manage blood flow and prevent excessive bleeding.
  • ➤ splenic artery
  • ➤ hilum of the spleen
